snowpack_detail.description:
• Recent snow moist to wet, depending on sun exposure. Once wet, slid easily on the hard snirt/old snow surface on slopes steeper than 35 degrees.
  • On N aspects above treeline, the recent snow was about 15 cm of creamy powder that was just becoming moist.
  • Snirt layer remained supportable until noon near and above treeline.
  • No signs of instability under the snirt. Moist, poorly bonded rounds were the predominate grain, but no planar failures
  • Below treeline, snowpack is moist to wet large, rounded grains. Little to no layering remains.

snowpack_detail.description:
We can split the snowpack into two elevation bands, above and below treeline, and the above treeline snow into two compass segments, northwest-north-northeast and east-south-west. Below treeline the snowpack is large, poorly bonded round grains wiht lots of dust mixed in. The snow has little strength. Fortunately, water is draining freely through it. It will stay in a steady state of weakness. You might be able to start a loose avalanche on steep slopes, if you push enough snow downhill.

There are several layers of white snow at the top of the snowpack on northwest-north-northeast aspects above treeline. They are recent storms, each topped by a melt-freeze crust. Then comes the distinct dust layer made up of large melt-freeze polycrystals. Just below the dust is a thin layer of small rounded grains, then some densely packed white windslabs. Under that, some older little-bit-dusty dusty snow. Lower layers are very slope dependent, a whole season of loading and faceting that is slowly making the transition to summer. The weak layers of concern are the recent melt-freeze crusts and around the distinct dust layer. With a cold snowpack in the morning, I was finding smooth breaks above and below the dust layer that took lots of force (CT25+ Q2). The breaks got easier and easier (CT10 Q2)as the snow warmed and softened.

On east-south-west aspects above treeline, there was little to no difference in the shallow layer of recent snow. Below the dust layer, the snowpack was mostly rounded grains. Areas with smaller rounds were stronger than areas with larger rounds. Again, test results on top of the dust got easier and easier as the snow warmed and softened.

Spent the weekend at Peter Estin hut. Toured up to Prospector peak. MASSIVE cornices that were incredibly sensitive. One was 20+ feet out and as I traversed the ridge along the visible rocks a 15' section ripped out and exposed my poor judgement, cracking under my outside ski and crashing down to the valley below. When they say traverse on the rocks they mean on them, not beside them. Wow. Great teaching moment. General stability was quite good with no natural action visible to us, although below tree line we saw a selection of crusts from sun crusts to what must have been rain action from a couple of weeks ago to a possible crust from really warm weather(?). Depth of the snowpack varied wildly and was very wind affected.

snowpack_detail.description:
Snowline in the Crestone area seemed to start around 9,000-9,200ft range. Only a few inches at most with moderate drifting. At the Rainbow Trail Junction, ground cover entailed about 5-8 inches of mostly powder. 
At the upper (old) 4x4 trailhead and beyond to treeline, snow depth was between 12-24 inches with ample drifting. The snowpack itself seemed quite stable. There was a hard layer about 6 inches under powder. Under this hard layer, the snowpack was 'firm'. 
We never worried about slides and only once heard a 'whoomf'. 
 
Things are fairly windblown (as usual) above treeline. South aspects are wind swept and clear. Eastern aspects are holding snow. However, with the high moisture content in the air, we witnessed HEAVY, HEAVY riming and feather ice above 13,000ft. Above 13,700ft, it was some of the denest, thickest rime I've ever seen in 20 yrs of mountaineering. 
We decided to forgo Crestone Needle in lieu of the conditions.
 
As we were packing to leave yesterday afternoon, it started to grapple, copiously. I can imagine how unstable this is going to make the snowpack. 
It wasn't all that cold, quite manageable actually.

snowpack_detail.description: I dug a pit yesterday on a SE aspect of Mt Trelease near tree line yesterday morning. Definitely found the slab layer that your reports have been discussing. It was not particularly reactive but did seem to have the potential to go big if it went. Beyond that there was no whumphing, settling or shooting cracks to report. I'm not sure if this sort of subjective info is of use to you or not (especially since it echoes your reports) but, thought I would pass it along and let you decide it is helpful.

I've been out of town for the past week and have no new snowpack observations to contribute. However, while reading your Steamboat zone snow discussion I noticed that you mention the rain crust layer buried at ~25cm. I know for a fact that this crust was formed on the evening of October 24th. At my observation location at 9K at the steamboat ski area I reported 9" of new snow on the morning of the 23rd, followed by an additional 2" of new snow on the morning of the 24th. there was a break in the weather during the day on the 24th and temps rose into the 30's. At approximately 1700 hours on the 24th, a steady rain started falling and continued throughout the night before changing back to snow at approximately 0600 hours on the 25th. I checked obs. from the Tower SNOTEL on the morning of the 25th and noticed an increase in moisture content of over 1.5" in a 12 hour period. I went skiing at the ski area on the 25th and was surprised to find the rain crust layer all the way to the summit at 10,300'. The crust was completely unbreakable. I noticed that on a west aspect the crust felt like frozen corn, but on a north facing slope the crust felt like a slick sheet of ice. I just wanted to pass along my obs. since I seem to be the only person I have talked to that remembers this rain event in October. Thanks for the reports, I like the new danger scale being used this season

snowpack_detail.description:
In the Topeka side, we were on a northerly aspect near TL.  There was 5-6" of new on top of older faceting snow, which lay on a finger hard slab that was 20-30 cm thick. This sat on old depth hoar.  Only did a quick hand pit so no test results.
In the niagara side, we skied a southerly aspect beginning abv TL and it was 6+" on supportable suncrust.  Overall, quite thin (less than 50cm), but the ground there is grass. The new snow was only cracking on ridgeline fairly localized around skis with little propagation.  Even with great prodding it was hard to get new soft slab at ridgeline to move very far on the old surface.  As expected, the slabbiness of the new snow on the southerly aspect decreased soon after leaving the ridgeline.  We only saw limited new avalanching that was a result of the new wind loading.  The two locations were cross loaded, abv TL on NE'erly aspects where new cornices had failed, popping out small, thin pockets.  Nothing widespread, or even big enough to enter as an avalanche. 
The quote of the day from John C while skinning up through the trees "the only thing supportable out here are the logs"

snowpack_detail.description: Following Storm #8, and over the weekend, we experienced ideal conditions for the formation of surface hoar at Red Mountain Pass - generally clear skies (until Sunday afternoon), a thick layer of relatively warm new snow (Storm 8) 'exhaling' large amounts of water vapor toward the comparatively very cold snowpack surface (losing heat via radiative cooling, night and day), otherwise high relative humidity, and light winds. Under these conditions, the feathery forms that are familiar along rivers on some winter mornings, 'growing' off trees, will grow off the snowpack surface creating a beautiful, sparkling new layer of tall and thin hoar crystals on top of the snowpack.  The attached photo shows a sample of surface hoar, in the shade, near Swamp Angel Study Plot yesterday (Sunday), not long before snow showers likely buried this incredibly delicate structure intact.  Depending on how extensive this crop of surface hoar was, and how well it was preserved under new snow and remains sheltered from wind and sun, this layer of surface hoar may prove to be a very important weak layer in the snowpack and be responsible for natural or human triggered avalanches later this season.  Surface hoar is implicated in many avalanche accidents in British Columbia, where the climatology is very favorable for its formation, but not quite as often a problem in Colorado.  Nonetheless, savvy backcountry skiers and ski patrollers pay very close attention to Colorado surface hoar layers.

We witnessed a natural avalanche today on Citadel's south shoulder. The slope is an east aspect, far above treeline, and released naturally from new wind-deposited snow load today. Time of release was 1310. We were on Trelease's north side so were across the valley, unable to get greater detail. The slide appeared to be a relatively thin soft slab and I'd guess R2D2 (150'across x 300'down x ~12") but, again, too hard to say from our vantage point. This was the only sign of instability we saw today throughout our tour. A profile dug at 11,400' on Trelease's north side gave CTH(26)Q1,SCx2 and ECT26,Q1 at ~100cm down (55cm from the ground) on 35-degree slope. Hard scores but dramatic results.

Average snowpack depth on these slopes was roughly 175cm, and consisted of surface hoar at the surface and a mixed bag of buried persistent weak layers beneath. A quick hasty pit revealed several buried surface hoar layer and two sun crusts in the upper mid-pack, as well as several layers of small and large facets in the lower mid-pack. Compression tests reacted to 4 of these layers with easy to moderate clean shears in the upper half of the snowpack, plus a harder clean shear down at the October/November interface. We saw no visible signs of recent avalanche activity, cracking, or collapsing. Conditions: Coverage was good, as was the skiing. Great powder skiing on the Northerlies, a supportable snowpack, and good fast riding conditions led us to stick to lower angle slopes

route: Rode snowmobiles up Buffalo Pass Road to approx. 10,000ft, then left our sleds and skied the North facing slopes into Bitch Creek. Our 'tour' consisted of laps on North through North-East aspects below treeline, around 9,500ft and 10,000ft in elevation

Quick test pit at 10800 on SE aspect was a couple feet of snow on dirt, new snow was on crust layer which was on -F layer of facets. Snowed the whole time, and never got above 0C. Also dug a pit a couple hundred yards south of this slide area http://avalanche.state.co.us/acc/acc_report.php?acc_id=72&accfm=off I posted a pit profile and more trip report photos on my flickr page, here, http://www.flickr.com/photos/rky_mtn_srfr/5245116782/ Splitboarded two runs between 10750'-9800' on easterly aspects, snow was great, face shots, but still a bit thin on coverage so turns were mellow. Below 9,800 snow coverage was too thin to risk hitting any land mines, so skied the trail out.

Monarch Pass observation. Skied backcountry both Sat and Sun afternoon. Regular wind eddy at pass on Saturday with winds NE. Winds Sunday were coming from south thru pass. About 50 inches of snow. Facets were further along than last week and there are a few crusts within bottom section of facets. New snow from this cycle is sitting on a light crust in some areas, and wind-firm snow in other areas. Mid-pack is not developed on north aspects below treeline as is easy to sink to the bottom even with all the new snow. Very dense slab near treeline and above yesterday. Lots of cracks, and lots of collapsing. East facing bowl (on east side of peak with summer chairlift at pass) had a natural that went, fracture was 24". Could not tell how far it propogated with conditions. Temp kept rising thru the day on Sunday. New snow was getting warmer/denser over the snow that fell Sat. Graupel was mixing in with snow early afternoon and accumulating on surface enough to notice. Dug pit last saturday on E aspect at 11,600 and found mostly facets, again with some light crusts within. At that time slab on top was not as developed and was shallow. Probably about 28" in pit then.

Top 20cm failed in 3 taps, the dense and cracking new snow, failed at 40cm with11 taps q2, 50cm at 17 taps q2, a dusty or debris layer at 70cm deep did not fail but a layer below would go at 100cm deep with very hard hits not on test. Some facets at ground

snowpack_detail.description: 10:30a Estimated class 3 avy observed on Dragon's Tail Couloir, Rocky Mountain National Park. Couloir is SE aspect ranging in steepness from 50 deg. near top to 25 deg near bottom at Emerald Lake. Conditions at time were heavy, dense snow; no wind, good visibility and warm temps of approx. 28 deg. F. Two experienced backcountry skiers equipped with full avy gear and formal training skinned up the slope between Dragon's Tail and Dead Elk Couloir with intent of skiing bottom apron of Dead Elk. At top of apron, just below large rock outcropping, skiers were in the process of digging pit when the roar of avy alerted them to the danger. Skiers witnessed 90 seconds of high speed slide that ran visibly 900'. Skiers unable to spot crown above but estimate the slide originated just below the top of couloir with a total approx. slide length of 1700'. Largest deposit at bottom was 300' wide with appox. depth of 20-30'. Skiers were within 40' proximity to the slide. Snowpack was approx. 3' deep with top layer composed of dense, heavy, new snow. Unable to complete pit assessment due to "completely freaking out". Prior to slide, skiers had not observed any whumping and minimal fracturing. No observation of recent natural releases though there was debris present from a slide some time ago

route: Dragon Tail

snowpack_detail.description: Skied in the Bear Lake Area of Rocky Mountain National Park today. The forecast seemed to be right on. Thus far, storm totals were in the 12 inch range, with more as you approached the divide. We had several reports of large loose snow natural avalanches (1000+ ft long) running above treeline in the Emerald Lake area. Sounds like some poor travel decisions lead to a close call with one of the naturals. Below treeline the snowpack is still pretty unconsolidated. New snow was weak in compression (CTE Q3) on some kind of NSF layer, but tests would not yield any other failures, nor would the new snow propagate with the ECT. Skiers were charging some steeper lines and not getting anything more than a bit of sluff on short, steep pitches (>35). I could hear the winds beginning to pick up as I left the parking lot, so I'm sure that things will continue to change.

The skin up was uneventful, but once we gained the ridge, instability was pretty obvious. Skinning along the ridge we noticed some shooting cracks and collapsing while breaking trail. We performed a ski cut across the top Riley 2 and remotely triggered a small slide below a small convex rollover maybe 100' downslope from the ridge (I'd say R1D1, maybe D2). Visibility was pretty terrible, but we also noticed a small natural avalanche (maybe R2D2) in Riley 3 that looks like it started at the interface between old snow and new snow, but stepped down to the ground and ran about a third of the way down the gulch; also broke on the rollover a hundred feet or so below the ridge; this natural looked like it happened recently. This was about noon today; the temp was 32deg on the ridge and was hammering wet, heavy snow. Pretty sketchy conditions

route: Bears Gulch

snowpack_observations.comments: Highly variable HS on these aspects. Generally 10cm of low density snow sitting on a mf crust in the upper snowpack. Midpack of stronger rounded grains. Lower snowpack 2mm facets.

NE and N aspects at treeline were very tender today. Moderate S and SW winds loading these slopes with fresh slabs. 15-20 cm thick at 1pm and growing. Slabs were easy to trigger with small cornice drops. Triggered remotely in one case from 20 feet away. Two weak layers in upper snowpack, one SH and small FC's, the other a reactive layer of DF's. New slabs only failed at these interfaces. Did not step down to older snowpack.

A couple weak layers in the upper 20cm of the snowpack on these aspects will be a concern with incoming snow. Found a reactive layer of df's about 10cm below the snow surface. Another layer of small facets and surface hoar 20cm below surface. On steep sheltered N aspects below treeline, could get some sluffs running in the upper 20 cm of snowpack

Stronger and supportive mid pack made up of small rounded grains.

Found 1-3mm facets in the lower snowpack on all aspects I dug on today.

Fresh wind slabs on N and NE aspects were tender and easily triggered.

Attached 2 profiles from SE and NE aspects at treeline.

snowpack_detail.description:
Green Mountain - Lower Headwall - 12.10.10
- Was up at Markley Hut Friday night and had 20cm new snow overnight which high winds blowing up valley from the west.   On Sat morning skied the lower headwall and there was significant cross loading onto the north facing slope.   Had significant settling, cracking, and whoomphing (up to 20' circles) while touring uphill.   HS was from 50 - 100cm with storm snow sitting on unsupportable facets.   

Devo (twin) Chutes, castle creek - 12.12.10
- Toured up the devo chutes in the afternoon and found HS ranging from 60-110cm.   Similar snowpack of that up by green mountain in that the new storm snow is sitting mostly on unconsolidated facets.   Did a quick pit in the lookers left chute about 2/3 way up.   Slope angle was low 30's.   HS - 110.   Layers of concern were depth hoar formation near the ground and a very persistant and noticable layer of buried surface hoar that was 30cm down from the top of the snowpack.   Quick test results:

CT6 Q1 - 30cm from surface on buried surface hoar layer
CT23 Q2 - At 10cm above the ground in depth hoar layer

snowpack_detail.description: In all 3 pits I dug, there was a Q1 failure 20cm below surface at the density change.  CT, ST, ECT all failed there at 1 tap.  Total new snow seemed to be in the 40cm range as this new stuff is settling fast.  I tried on several 38 deg+ slopes to get them to avalanche, but could not even produce a crack.  Also, I saw absolutely zero avalanches anywhere.  This was the same for Susan on Coal Bank and Molas.  I had decent visibility in the alpine as well.  A surprise to me, but I don't deal in 15-20% snow very often.  Abv TL on leeward slopes, the upper pack was a 1F- slab sitting on the low density from Saturday.  I was supported by it on my skis, but boot pen broke right through to the bottom.  Blw TL, this slab was 4F.  It acted like it would support my skis, but then I would break through.  I suppose it just needs more load to fail.  Thought 2" H20 would have done it.  I also stayed in fairly conservative terrain as I was solo.

snowpack_detail.description:
From the top down:
  • HN 2-3" of very nice stellars. Drifting up to 6" deep in pockets above treeline, usually topped with a thin 4F to 1F wind crust. Some SS activity in the new snow off very steep slopes above treeline, but I was unable to trigger anything
  • Crust and snirt (obvious dust) layer. This was variable, both in make-up and thickness. At the worst, the crust was less than an inch thick and not supportable. Most places the crust was 2 to 4 inches thick and frozen solid. Thinner crusts were recent snow above the snirt layer. Thicker crusts were melted or scoured down to the snirt layer
  • Old windslabs above treeline. Rounded, strong.
  • Loose rounded grains. Old facets that are well rounded, but have little strength. Most prevalent near and below treeline.

snowpack_detail.description:
Ascent on S/SE-facing slopes from Long Lake to Pawnee Pass.  At lower elevations (10800-11000') the snow was quickly turning wet by mid-morning.  ENE-facing slopes above the pass (~12700) showed no obvious signs of instability.  Descent on short but steep ENE aspects did not trigger any instabilities.   

Remainder of descent was on S/SE-facing slopes to about 11700'.  The snow was quite variable, from creamy spring snow, to wet velocity reducing snow, to soft shallow powder in shaded tree-areas.

No signs of recent avalanches were observed during the tour.  Steep, N/NNE facing couloirs on opposing ridgelines (south of Long/Isabelle lakes) did not have any signs of recent avalanches, but there were signs of cross-loading.

snowpack_detail.description: HN about 10 cm, sitting on top of M/f crust.  4/25 snow has melted and 4/25 dust layer is on top of/within the crust in most areas (even north aspects).  Bonding and stability were poor in areas where the sun was hitting.  There were a lot of natural point releases, mostly near exposed rocks and cliffs, but on all aspects.  Many appeared to be from yesterday, but, some were from today, and one fairly large R2,D2 ran while we were skiing.  One of my partners kicked off a small wet slide on the north face of Radiobeacon at 1030 am.  started from her skis, then fanned out a little, entraining more debris, and ran about 800-100 feet downslope and into couloirs on the west side of the lower part of the face.  Other natural point releases we observed on east aspects, were entraining a lot of snow and running far.  All ran on dust/crust layer about 10c down. Crust was supportable on all aspects,and down to 9200 feet at 1230

snowpack_detail.description: Out at St. Marry's Glacier today with some friends to do some Beacon practice and dig a few pits to keep up the skills. While there was some not sure how old avy degree at the bottom of the lake near the cliff band the snow was stable. We dug one pit on the North East side of the lake near the trees but was in the sun about 4'. We did the shovel compact test counting to seven with our shoulder and got no fracture. We could still see the loose snow from last Oct near the ground and it was interest we did the test on the column then dug down to the next layer, did the test again and it did not fracture until we got to the layer above the snow from Oct. About 3 hits and a big slab came off our column. Hope this is helpful. My best, Tim=

snowpack_detail.description: We traversed under the W face of Pacific finding 2-3cm new snow on top of P hard. I figure that's a sun/wind combo, our edges barely bit. The wind was L gusting to M a few times, from the S, the shoulder of Pacific was shaping the wind movement it seemed. We crossed a few wind loaded gullies etc, finding no CR or CO but anywhere from 10-50cm. These were isolated, the W face couloirs on Pacific looked pretty blown out, down to the dust layer in a few spots. 12,400ft we spotted a large recent (last 24hr) natural avi on Half Dome (pt 12,561ft N of Mayflower Hill) a ENE aspect ~12,500ft. From what we could see it looked more like a SS than wet. SS-N-D2.5-R3-0. She ran almost all the way to the basin floor, and pulled some small trees down at the bottom. We also witnessed several small wet sloughs coming off some low, out of the wind, N facing rock bands. We skied down into Humbug Gulch and experienced everything from hollow hard slabs, powder, corn, heavy corn and slush. The window of perfect snow was 15-20min in areas protected from the wind. We traversed through the S trees and found them to be fairly supportive ~12:30. Once out of the wind it was hot, breaking trail with just ~5cm new was slow and sticky. The layering we saw up high looks more like winter than spring. Hard wind slabs and a exposed sun crust or two over softer less supportive snow. The wind is being deceptive and keeping certain areas cool. We didn't dig any formal data or test plus pits. Cheers.=

snowpack_detail.description: Coal Bank pass. Pit: aspect- SE 120; elev- 11200; incline- 30; precip- s1; wind loading- yes; sky- obscured; wind- S (L). 50cm of high density storm snow sitting on a crust facet matrix 30-40cm from ground. There were 2 distinguishible crust with weak facets between and below. Base of the pack was 1mm facets showing signs of bonding. The bottom 10cm were 2mm facets, some of which are still retaining their cup shape; these were showing signs of bonding as well. Surface temp was -3.5C with a ground temp of 0.3C. Temps taken every 10cm revealed weak temperature gradients throughout the entire pack; no change greater than or equal to 1C / 10cm. Problem layer was the facets below the lower crust. Test results at this layer were CT13Q1, ECTP17 Q1/2, and PST 22/100 (End, 60cm down, 101220). Trail breaking was difficult with high density wind transported new snow. We experienced localized whoomphing on flat slope and on east 1/4 aspects. There was some minor cracking and whoomping while skiing slope 30 degrees and less. One crack propegated 10m and the slab popped but didn't move as one person traversed the top of a wind loaded gully moving to an island of safety; if the slope was steeper, we would have expected the slab to pull out. We observed some snowfall rates of S3 during periods throughout the day. Visibility was 100m so we stayed below treeline.

Skiing exceeded my expectations. Dust layer currently mostly covered in Pearl Basin. Skiing great now.

snowpack_detail.description: Skiing in Buff Pass area yesterday. Heavy snowfall most of the day. probably 8-10" of new snow. Top snow was very reactive on steeper slopes. Mostly 6" deep new snow clearing out of normal slide areas. Largest slide, result of a ski cut, was 12-18" crown, wind load, and ran a good distance into trees below. Great powder skiing in most areas. Pit dug early am with only 3-4" of new on top, North facing, 9500' elevation, 25 degree slope. Failed at ground on isolation, but had good stiffness throughout. 140 cm total depth. C17 / Q1 / 20 cm down on crust from 3-4 days ago. C22 / Q2 / 60cm down, and C26 / Q1 / 75cm down. No failure on October snow layer that was very visible 30 cm from ground

snowpack_detail.description: Dug a pit on NNE aspect @ 10,000ft. Total snowpack depth: 220cm. Snowpack consisted of nearly a meter of consolidated new snow, the December 12 crust buried a meter deep, and several deeply buried surface hoar layers sandwiched between consolidated snow. Compression tests reacted to the Dec 12 with moderate clean shears @ 110cm from surface, as well hard clean shears @160cm and @180cm from surface on old buried surface hoar layers. Our Extended Column Test (ECT) yielded no results. We had good visibility and saw no signs of recent avalanche activity other than a couple of recent small snowcat-triggered sluffs from earlier in the day on South facing slopes. No cracking or collapsing was observed.

West side of the the main meadow but East of the cornice. E-NE face 25degree slope,11,800ft, with moderate precip and 10-20MPH winds. No evidence of recent activity in any area during the tour. Found 115cm with 25cm fist harness 1mm powder sitting atop a knife hardness ice crust sandwiching some 3mm faceted on another ice crust @ 70cm and then 2mm finger/pencil all the way to the ground. Results were CT23 Q2 @72cm, and STH Q2 72cm. Of note, besides the pleasant lack of tracks, while traversing down and across to the left on a 27-28 degree section of the descent, 150 yds below our pit, I experienced some slight whomphing, and then a shooting crack 2-3" wide that ran 20 feet ahead of me on my line, and then shot 50-75 feet back and down towards my right. The slope held, and we carried on without incident, enjoying some real nice lines. Once down in the trees, it obviously thickened up just a little but, but not until the hike (10,300) out of the gully did the snow start to fell heavy with moisture. Safe Travels, Ty=

Observed a small soft slab slide 300 yards below first bridge up Pearl Pass road going to the Tagert Hut. The slide was about 75 yards wide covering the road with about 6 to 18 inches of debris. The slide happened about 5:15 p.m. on the east facing slope and was a natural slide (not skier triggered.)=

we had to turn back on our initial move to the ridge from the pass parking lot do to large propagating cracks around the trees,sign #1.We ended up going up the power line cut and rode back down the power line cut.halfway up the cut we experienced woomphing and cracking as we took the skinner off to the right of the cut.We went up for a second run and took the tighter trees between the power line cut and the perfect trees in here more of the same cracking and woomphing as we got down to the skinner out just 100 yards up from our exit was what appeared to be a natural slide with large debree right at the bottom of this tree run.The crown was 2,1/2-3,4 foot deep it ripped between both large trees and small trees that where right at the height of the snow pack.This little slide went to the ground or close to it at the burried weak crust over facets.We also saw slides on the back side of this ridge on the easterly aspect triggered at the cornice around rock outcrop.When we got back to the parking lot there was a big crown staring us in the face across the parking lot that c-dot ripped out right on the convex role.In retrospect we probably should not have been out yesterday 12/20/10,with conservative choices we made it out safe.There is activity on all aspects with large slide potential out there people be careful

snowpack_detail.description: I did some compression test on an East aspect near the summit of Marble Peak at around 11,000ft. Results: I had and easy failure CT1 with a Q1 or Q2 shear quality in the upper snowpack. Most likely the interface between the new snow from the day before and the older snow. The rest of the collum did not fail. The next test I did yielded no failure, but the top layer, fist hardness, simply dissolved. The depth of the snow where I dug was surprisingly well over a meter. I did not notice any faceting near the base, which was surprising. There was a crust layer about 60cm up from the base, but it did not produce failure. The snowpack overall seemed quite variable, and near the ridgetop it I noticed a 5cm crust. I also notice a bit of cracking off of ski tracks in the main Marble bowl (11,000ft east facing). Lower down there was not enough snow to produce slabs. Thanks for the forecasts,

snowpack_detail.description: We dug a pit and did a reutschblock test that failed upon the first ski weighting the block RB2Q3. The fracture failed on facets above a crust about a foot from the ground. It was a very uneven fracture (Q3), a soft slab of all the new snow, and we were on a mellow slope only about 200 ft long so we decided to ski  despite the easy failure. The Q3 proved to be a big part of the test because even though it failed easily there was no ability to propogate a fracture. We ended up working our way to steeper slopes and eventually jumped off cliffs upwards of 35 ft with no activity.

Very unusual pit profile in that many prominent layers were apparent but they had virtually no diffference in hardness. Total height of snow was 60cm. Surface facets were very obvious on the surface and the top 10 cm was unconsolidated snow even though there had been no new snow and some wind the previous two days. Buried surface facets at 5o cm., buried surface hoar at 40 cm., depth hoar layer 22-25 cm. and depth hoar from ground to 5cm. All layers fist or slightly harder for entire depth of snow. snowpack_detail.description: We skied the backcountry both directions from Wolf Creek Pass this past weekend and found a uniformly thin snow pack for this time off year--100 cm thick in most northerly aspects in the trees and more open areas as well. There was 4-5 inches of surface hore on top of a pretty hard 18-24 inch slab before in degenerated into sugar at the bottom. Sure, pretty typical for an "early San Juan snowpack," but lots of hidden obstacles just below the surface add extra danger to the backcountry traveler this season. And with the long range forcast not so favorable we expect that the sugar at the bottom will only degenerate further. Saw lots of frosted flakes on the north side of Alberta's Cousin that were real pretty

Treeline and alpine areas showed extensive drifting and slabs formation from southerly winds. Heavy cross loading on easterly aspects and some very deep, wind loaded pillows in the start zones of northeast aspects near treeline. All of this wind slab formation occurred AFTER the natural cycle. North through east aspects near and above treeline looked ripe for triggering in the loaded areas.

snowpack_detail.description:
Large natural slide in Trelease Bowl. From Dale Atkins:

"Last week's cycle was impressive but it did not come close to comparing with the Feb 1986 and Feb 1995 cycles. Interestingly, there is no record of this path running in '86 (probably the biggest cycle since the late 1880s, at least -- locally -- until the 1995 cycle hit). In this immediate area, the Feb 1995 cycle produced many more, and also bigger and thicker avalanches than Dec 2010. At least one in the 1995 cycle was much thicker. Trelease ran in Feb 1995 but was unremarkable. There were some big avalanche cycles in the 1950s, but back in those days, no one recorded slides on Trelease"

snowpack_detail.description:
Had to alter original tour plan due to very shallow snowpack on W-SW aspects below treeline. Trailhead at around 9000 ft had only around 10cm snowpack on west facing terrain. 

Looking around this area of the Elks, terrain above 12,500 or so has been heavily wind effected in the past two weeks. Distribution of slabs seems somewhat random with odd loading patterns due to strong winds from variable directions. Bare ground often next to loaded pillows in start zones.

Dug one profile, north aspect of Sheep Mtn, below treeline at around 10,000 ft. Surface hoar layer buried around the 24th or 25th of November was the most significant weak layer. It was buried down 30 cm in this profile and failed with moderate Q1 results in CT's and ECT's (ECTP 12). Mid pack consisted of rounded snow from the late October storm up to 1F hardness, lower snowpack was 2mm facets.

Got a good look at the southerly aspects of Arkansas Mtn from across the valley. At and below treeline slopes facing south still have a very shallow and patchy snowpack.HS probably averaged under 25 cm for areas that did have snow.

October ice lens still obvious at 10-15 cm above ground. Faceting occurring above this layer at 15-39 cm. This is the layer of greatest concern where stability tests failed. Hard results though, suggesting low probability of triggering, but potential high consequence results. Consistent with MODERATE avalanche danger. Facets and early signs of depth hoar below 15 cm. snowpack_detail.description: We were touring on Green Mtn above Markley Hut in the upper Castle Creek valley in Aspen and found a slide path from a couple days ago (during the previous small storm that dropped a few inches). We estimate the crown was about a meter deep and it ran for about 400ft. It was on an east facing aspect below a rock outcropping. It might have been triggered by a skier...I would like to link in a pic that we took but where do I do that? We also dug a pit on the west side of Green Mtn at about 12000' and the snow was highly unstable. After three light hand pats on a test section we found the large consolidated slab of snow from the big wet storm broke on a buried hoar layer that was 6-8" deep. It basically would have run to the ground. Super sketchy conditions on that west side. We skied trees on the N-NW facing aspect out of there.

New storm snow forming into soft wind slabs in Eureka area. I triggered a small hillside sympathetically from below around 11 o'clock today. Looks like the last storm surface has seen some surface hoar and bonding; if we get a lot from this there could be some impressive wind slabbing

snowpack_detail.description: Saturday-Sunday there was fairly sizable surface hoar all across Grand County. Cloudy nights on Sunday-Monday helped lessen this. The snow seemed to be melting some of the snow. The melt also preceeded a deeper hollow crust on exposed snow

I skied from the Friends hut to Ashcroft through Pearl Pass this morning. I left Friends hut at around 8am. Made it through Pearl Pass with limited visibility, but seemingly light snowfall and high winds. Skied off the pass and down across the flats in high winds, and drifting snow without incident, noticing a couple pockets of significant wind loading. I decided to descend from the Mace saddle down flatter terrain and enter a North/Northwest facing slope that comes off the shoulder of Greg Mace peak, I believe this slope is referred to as the Backyard pitch of the Tagert hut. I thought the winds would be lighter lower down and did not expect the wind loading to be as significant. At this time it was around 9:30 and had been storming for around 4 or 5 hours. When entering the slope I took lower entry angle that was wind scoured and was attempting to ski down across the path to lower angled terrain. As soon as I entered the path, at roughly 11,600 feet, the entire slope in front and above me, which were significantly steeper, fractured about 12inches deep and slide about 1000 feet down the path. The slopes farther out in front of me sympathicly released about the same depth and slide down the path. The wind scoured spot where I was standing did not slide and I stood there and watched to slope break into blocks and slide. The Slide was most likely D2; the debris was only 2 to 3 feet deep but had large blocks of wind slab roughly the size of tabletops. This slide only involved the new snow and did not step down into older layers. The wind had loaded the slope much faster than I expected, the wind drifts higher in the slope where clearly steep and large enough to slide. It seemed the entire basin was loading into this area. Therefore that slab could have involved snow from Sunday nightâ€™s storm that transported onto this pitch.

snowpack_detail.description: I also saw a slide that released during the day on the ESE aspect of the "Matchstick Hill" on the NE side of Vail Pass. This would be the ESE aspect of the pronounced S-facing bowl that drains into Corral Creek, which always has a stout cornice at the top. It looked like it ran the full distance of the path, 11,800' to 11,300', but we could only see a side view from Corral Creek on our way out. We skied one bowl to the West & found poor bonding below the earliest drizzle layer (~10 days old) which was 10"-14" below Sunday's drizzle layer. There was another weak layer ~18" above the ground between faceted snow layers. Also, plenty of surface hoar grew sunday night out of the drizzle layer. Looks like we'll be on the mellower slopes for awhile...=

snowpack_detail.description: NE facing aspect on 35 degree slope with slight cross loading. Noted 7 inches of heavy new snow resting on a smaller layer of lighter snow, with that layer resting on 8 inches of well-consolidated snow. This slab (overall about 17 inches) was on top a very weak,sugary layer. During tests, the new snow slab failed after two taps at the wrist. After digging a pit, the new snow slab failed immediately after a 180 pound skier step onto the isolated block. With one small bounce on the same block, the snow failed down to the weak buried layer, creating a 17 inch slab. During travels that day, we noted numerous whumping and setting sounds, especially on south east and south facing aspects. Did a pit (70 cm) on a low angle ESE aspect in an open park in the trees....ECTP19 Q1 on the ice crust on top of the October snow. The crust was easy 2" thick, in places 4" thick and anchored well to the ground. There was 5 cm of 3 mm facets on top of the crust. Will be hard to get rid of it. CT also Q1 think 12 taps. Minimal cracking and collapse during the tour. 
RB score of 3, Q1, popped right off the ice crust. 
There was also a thin wind crust under the 4" of newer snow, but couldn't get anything to go off it. 
There was a crust on westerly aspects too, but not much snow. Some nice tracks dropping in off to the west of the tour in a gully feature. Looked like some good turns to be had, but I got way to frozen to even think along those lines. 
The trail in was fine with skins on, brutal coming out....very thin and lots of rocks

snowpack_detail.description:
Wind Effect: westerly aspects were generally scoured clean near ridge tops.

Snow Surface:easy skin conditions in loosely packed new snow that was 10-15cm deep in terms of skin-pen. Recent drifting was obvious on isolated terrain features.

Riding Conditions: descending through the trees was very good. Snow was supportable and the coverage was most likely better than at any point last season. There were very few snags and very little evidence of rocks or buried stumps.

Snowpack Discussion:dug a quick pit at the bottom of the ironing board, about 30m below tree line: punched through to the ground when I clicked out, depth was 96cm on a SW (230) slope that was 33 degrees in pitch, at 83cm there was breakable sun crust that was 1/2cm thick, mid-pack between 80 and 40cm was F to 4F, 40-28cm is the October buried crust and it was K on top and blue-grey ice below, 28cm to ground was 1-2mm facets. In terms of test results: STM 83cm Q2, STH 40cm Q3, CT11 83cm SC and CT25 40cm SP. Given the hard results, Iâ€™d guess trigging a slab on a 30 degree slope would be a challenge, but if a fracture were initiated it would run fast on the October crust.

Greatest Point of Danger:after test results, I felt that being at the bottom of the ironing board was notable danger. Leaving the truck, my objective was to ski the ironing board. However, I pulled the skins and milked good turns through the old growth trees.

area: we left the truck at the parking lot across the highway from the c-dot building just above Arapahoe basin. Crossing into the north fork of the snake river drainage, I skinned up the valley floor until turning east into the trees on the south side of â€œDaveâ€™s Waveâ€ avalanche path. After 40 minutes or so, we reached tree line at the bottom of â€œthe ironing boardâ€, and I dug a quick pit.

snowpack_detail.description:
10,550', SE, 20 deg, HS 170cm, HST 35cm

Both deeper layers had thin icy crust, upper crust immediately under storm snow was 0.5-1 cm thick, lower crust very thin. storm snow with easy failure on upper ice, deeper snowpack with hard compressive failures- clean planar- on both lower thin ice, and on lower layer (surface hoar?) that was not readily seen in pit. Skiing and probing indicated the N facing slopes did not have (or very reduced) thick ice layer and SW and S slopes had exaggerated upper ice layer (sun crust rahter than melt or rain crust???). Skiing from 10,500' - 8500' indicated snow acting a loose powder, not slab forming. Sunday 12/19 - same area -additional 20+ cm storm snow, getting warmer and damper (fog, wet snow, approx 30F+, with occasional W gusts of 20MPH) into afternoon, storm snow showing increasing slab tendencies. Skiing at 9500' on a S facing coxcomb-like ridge, and playing on the 25 degree SW side,I kicked off a soft cross-loading cornice above the steep SE face (small rockband and 40 degrees + slope). Cornice fell, triggering a 24" soft slab size 1-2, that ran on what appeard to be the more recent near-surface ice crust layer on the lee SE slopes on/below rockband. DID NOT appear to step down. Soft debris ran about 250' and stopped as small soft slab pieces on 15-20 degree slope above trees.

Email From: John Keffler Email Address: john.w.keffler@gmail.com Contact Number: 303-971-3766 On Saturday, myself and a friend headed up to see what the snow pack was above Mines 1 and 2 at Berthoud pass looked like. We dug a pit just above the hanging snow field that builds up above Mines 1 and 2. We were above Mines 2 but off to the east side. What we found (working from the top down) was a 3 inch finger hard layer, then about 6 inches of softer snow that you could remove easily with your hand then a very hard 5 inch slab (pencil hard). The bottom layer was about 8 inches of sugar snow. Seeing this we headed over to the Shoulder and skied the trees, not to mention that Mine 1 and 2 are not filled in yet. Granted that this was up above the hanging snow field and that this area is really exposed and gets a lot of wind, it was not good news for that area. It was just a chance for us to keep building our experience and trying to see what the snow is doing this year so far. Hope this helps. I have a few picture I could send you if you like too. Thanks Guys, -John=

snowpack_detail.description: Hi, My partner and I headed out of the Eldora ski resort Tuesday morning,and toured to the Lost Lake area just west of the resort. We ski cut "right chute" N aspect, 10,500', 40+ degrees. There was about 1.5 meters of snow in the start zone, 50 or so of new (Fist hard)from the most recent event, about the same of older snow (1 finger) and then a crust, knife/pencil hard, then 30 or so of facets and depth hoar below that. We were able to penetrate the buried crust with our skis, and were going to the ground with our cuts in most places. The storm slab was pretty thick and heavy, and, likely due to a remarkable lack of wind in our area throughtout the event, not very reactive at all. We had a couple of large frightenening whumpfs in the start zone itself, but nothing in the flats above. The whole start zone whumpfed under my weight, but never got going, even though the slope angle where I was standing was over 40 degrees. The storm slab seemed to lack the cohesion and "energy" to initiate propagation. The diamonds between our cuts were sliding on a layer of facets above the crust. Some of them went crashing into the lowest cuts, but didn't initiate anything. It appeared that the meter or so of snow in the lower angle bottom part of the chute was well bonded enough, and providing enough support, to hold up the rest. Or maybe we just missed the sweet spot. It's worth noting that the bottom of the chute had little snow before the 12/11 event. About 75 vertical feet below the top of the chute, the buried crust disappeared and the angle moderated to around 35 degrees. The whumpfing had stopped, and the snow felt pretty consistent with the "ski pole penetrometer". We unroped and skied to the bottom of the chute and through a low-angle part of the bowl below. No further signs of instability noted. Hope this is helpful! Colin=

We triggered numerous size 1 slides today in treeline terrain in RMNP on short, steeper (35-40) slopes. However, the biggest slide was SS-AS-D2-R2-I (1-2'deep x 500' wide x 600' long @ 11,600' on NE aspect). We found this instability all over but feel this slope mentioned above avalanched largely due to it's proximity to a large cliff that constantly sluffs and created a slightly more dense slab. Other slides were much smaller/localized. It snowed nearly all day, S1 to S2 at times. Good skiing, no, great skiing...what a great start to the winter! Thanks for your hard work!=

Everything from shade to sunny spots were covered with what must have been an inch thick layer. Crazy crinkley sounds when making turns. I suppose we'll have to keep an eye on that one as the next week layer?

Flurries (some intense) Thursday led to clear and warm conditions through Sunday AM.

snowpack_detail.description: 1-2 cm surface hoar formed friday and saturday night in open areas at and below TL. While sun was visibly degrading the SH on southerly aspects, the layer was likely buried intact on most aspects by Sunday night snowfall. 1 recent avalanche observed, on Wingle Ridge on a NE aspect, SE of point 11977. Snowmobile track dropping off cornice leads me to surmise a snomo trigger. Numerous snowmobile highmark and traverse tracks buried/erased by the release & debris. I'd call it a HS-AMu-R1-D1-O. Can send a long-range pic if you like. Other snowmo cornice-huck tracks were nearby, with no avalanche triggered. Lots of highmark activity in that entire bowl, as usual. Dug 2 snowpits in close proximity, near TL, SE of Shrine Mountain, at about 11,700' on ENE aspect, 30+ degree slope. Did not make detailed pit measurements, but profiles were about 2m HS, new snow/SH at surface, firm to stiff (4F to 1F+) wind slabs on top of depth hoar. Decomposing SH/NSF layer (~0.5 - 1mm grains) at about 60 cm depth was primary weak layer. 4 CT's: SH/NSF layer produced consistently CTM14-16, Q2. Depth hoar was a consistent CTH25-27, Q3. Several other wind/snow event density contrasts were highlighted by moderate shovel shears, but did not respond to CTs.

snowpack_observations.comments: Surface scoured and slabbed. Shallow, pockety, recent windslabs sheared easily and were reactive to ski cuts. I avoided areas where the new windslabs were extensive enough to pose a hazard. Lots of filling-rattling sastrugi.

Areas with nicely drifted, soft snow. Turning creamy with mid-day sun. Ski pen 20 cm over very hard slabs (see pit). When the deep weak layers went, it was with a serious pop. Columns were heavy enough that it was hard to lift out of the pit.

Highly variable, wind-impacted snow surface.
  • Soft, creamy snow on wind sheltered, sunny slopes.
  • Soft near surface facets and precip particles on wind sheltered, shaded slopes.
  • Slopes that were not sheltered had variable wind crusts. Mostly 4F to 1F and less than 10 cm thick.
20 to 30 cm of surface facets and precip particles. Underlying slab from 12/20 has settled into strong, supportable 1F slab. Good riding and excellent coverage for this time of year.

snowpack_detail.description: Hi, I am a guide working for Southwest Adventure Guides and wanted to relay our test pit observations from our Level 1 Avalanche class today. Our test pit was dug in the Little Molas Lake area, on a NE aspect at 10970', on a 22 degree slope. We found a total snow depth of 133cm with a significant developing layer of surface hoar. UPPER: The upper snow pack was roughly 80cm and comprised mostly of decomposing fragments. We had repeatable reactions to compression tests on layers 30cm & 45cm below the surface. Both of these interfaces were hard to initiate (CT21&22) and resulted in Q1 and Q2 sheers. MID: Roughly 80cm down we found a very thin melt freeze crust layer, although we had no reactions on this layer. LOWER: Roughly 40cm of basal facets (1-1.5mm) still persist, however, they appear to be beginning to round. We had hard to initiate results within the basal facet layer during a deep tap test.

snowpack_observations.comments: Minimal wind effects on these slopes today. Shallow new slabs were confined to ridge tops and did not extend down into start zones.
Layer of surface facets found 20-40 cm below the surface. Reactive with ski cuts on steeper test slopes. Several D1 soft slabs today failed on this layer.

Well developed surface hoar layer below treeline on these aspects. Buried down 25 cm at lower elevations. Grains up to 6mm in size. Failed easily on tilt test and compression test though new snow above this layer was too low density today to be reactive. With more loading it will be a problem in sheltered, steep slopes.

snowpack_detail.description:
HS in this area averaged 1.8-2 meters below treeline. At treeline, HS near 2.5 meters. 

Weak layers of surface facets and surface hoar present in the upper snowpack on all northerly aspects today. Depth varied from 10-40 cm below the snow surface depending on elevation. These weak layers will be a concern for natural and triggered slides for the next few days with the incoming storm. 

Strong mid pack of rounded grains from last week's storm. With some probing to the ground could still feel a weaker layer of facets on bottom of the snowpack.

route: Up north ridge of Justice from quarry road to summit at 11,700, Descent on N-NW aspects into N Anthracite drainage. Skin back up SW aspects to Anthracite Pass and down lower half of the Marble bowl run out.
objective: Check weak layers in upper snowpack for incoming storm. Check effects of last week storm on snowpack here.

weather_detail.description: Heavy winds and variable (W-SW-S) yesterday transported snow from recent precip, but amount available for transport was not significant (3-8 cm) due to melt/freeze crusts and settling over sunny Christmas weekend. Most windward areas were scoured to the old snow surface and small to moderate increase in cornices was visible, although I think most of the suspended snow went to Wyoming or Kansas. 6 cm of dry snow fell overnight in light to moderate winds.

snowpack_observations.comments: Cracking within the newly formed slab (4f) produced cracks up to 10 yards. Cold slow moving snow on steeper slopes.
Using a probe pole, could feel very weak snow layering below mid pack slabs...likely large faceted grains. This layer is between 20 and 30 cm's thick. Probe pole drops through with little resistance.

snowpack_detail.description: Wind is creating a fresh shallow slab on the surface. Cracking was common, though uneventful. Probed depths at the upper end of the near TL elevation band ranged from 95 to 145 cm's. Dense mid pack. On southerly aspects, could feel three distinct thin crusts first being just below the newly formed surface slab. Way too cold to dig a formal snowpit.

route: Parked on hwy and headed up towards Waterdog Lakes. Then headed to the NE to Banana Mtn. Did not go too much higher than tree line...way too cold. Skied back a similar way.
objective: To see where my tolerance for the cold is at these days. And to check out an area that has been getting more and more use these days.
